original_data.question: A 29-year-old woman presents to her OB/GYN for a preconception visit. She wishes to become pregnant within the next several months. A thorough history reveals that the patient suffers from phenylketonuria (PKU). She recalls being instructed by prior physicians to follow a diet that avoids certain foods; however, she admits to not being complaint with these recommendations. Laboratory testing reveals a plasma phenylalanine level of 20.2 mg/dL (normal range <2 mg/dL). Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient?

options.A: Improved PKU treatment will decrease the risks of spontaneous abortion and intrauterine fetal death
options.B: 3 months prior to conception, begin a restricted diet to lower phenylalanine levels to below 6 mg/dL
options.C: Begin a phenylalanine-restricted diet in your first trimester to reduce the risk of fetal morbidity
options.D: Your current phenylalanine levels do not pose a risk to any future pregnancy

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
The time period prior to conception.
Observed to be or have been pregnant.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Record and study of past events.

A group of autosomal recessive disorders marked by a deficiency of the hepatic enzyme PHENYLALANINE HYDROXYLASE or less frequently by reduced activity of DIHYDROPTERIDINE REDUCTASE (i.e., atypical phenylketonuria). Classical phenylketonuria is caused by a severe deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase and presents in infancy with developmental delay; SEIZURES; skin HYPOPIGMENTATION; ECZEMA; and demyelination in the central nervous system. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p952).

A group of autosomal recessive disorders marked by a deficiency of the hepatic enzyme PHENYLALANINE HYDROXYLASE or less frequently by reduced activity of DIHYDROPTERIDINE REDUCTASE (i.e., atypical phenylketonuria). Classical phenylketonuria is caused by a severe deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase and presents in infancy with developmental delay; SEIZURES; skin HYPOPIGMENTATION; ECZEMA; and demyelination in the central nervous system. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p952).
A formal and organized process of transmitting knowledge to a person or group.
Regular course of eating and drinking adopted by a person or animal.
Substances taken in by the body to provide nourishment.
Advice telling someone what the best thing to do is.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
The residual portion of BLOOD that is left after removal of BLOOD CELLS by CENTRIFUGATION without prior BLOOD COAGULATION.
An essential aromatic amino acid that is a precursor of MELANIN; DOPAMINE; noradrenalin (NOREPINEPHRINE), and THYROXINE.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.
Any act or phenomena, or behavior, constituting a reply or reaction of a living organism or its part to some foregoing stimulus or agent.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
